posts.text: å› ä¸ºPodcastçš„descriptionåªèƒ½åœ¨feedUrlé‡Œæ‰¾åˆ°ï¼Œæ— æ³•ç›´æ¥è·å–ï¼Œè€ŒfeedUrlæ˜¯xmlæ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥è·å–ä¹‹åè¦å…ˆè½¬æˆjsonæ ¼å¼ã€‚parseString importè‡ªxml2jsçš„built-inæ–¹æ³•ã€‚ ä¿®æ”¹å‰ï¼šç›´æ¥æ¥æ”¶parseStringçš„è¿”å›å€¼ 12345678910111213141516const desc = parseString(data, (err, result) => { if (err) { return } // console.log(result) // const { rss } = result // const { channel } = rss // const { description } = channel[0] const { description } = result.rss.channel[0] // console.log(channel) console.log(description) // æ­£å¸¸å€¼ return description }) è¾“å‡ºçš„ç»“æœæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ­£å¸¸å€¼ï¼Œä½†è¿”å›åˆ°jsonä¸­å´æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªåˆè‡­åˆé•¿çš„å¯¹è±¡ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚ ä¿®æ”¹åï¼šåˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªPromiseï¼ŒPromiseé‡Œé¢æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªå‡½æ•°ï¼ˆexecutor, which is called automaticallyï¼‰ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªexecutorçš„å‚æ•°resolveå’Œrejectæ˜¯ä¸¤ä¸ªå›è°ƒå‡½æ•°ï¼ˆç”±jsæœ¬èº«æä¾›ï¼‰ 123456789101112131415161718const desc = await new Promise((resolve, reject) => parseString(data, (err, result) => { if (err) { reject(null) } else { // console.log(result) // const { rss } = result // const { channel } = rss // const { description } = channel[0] const { description } = result.rss.channel[0] // console.log(channel) console.log(description) resolve(description) } })).catch(error => { console.log(error) }) // è®°å¾—å¤„ç†rejectçš„æƒ…å†µï¼ï¼ï¼å¦åˆ™ä¼šæŠ¥é”™ï¼æš‚æ—¶çš„ç»“è®ºï¼šawaitåªæœ‰å½“resolvedåæ‰ä¼šè¿”å›givençš„resultï¼Œå¦‚æœæ˜¯rejectedçš„æƒ…å†µï¼Œä¼šæŠ›å‡ºé”™è¯¯ï¼Œéœ€è¦catchå¤„ç†ã€‚ æˆåŠŸï¼ é‡ç‚¹ï¼šWhen the executor obtains the result, be it soon or late, doesnâ€™t matter, it should call one of these callbacks: resolve(value) â€” if the job is finished successfully, with result value. reject(error) â€” if an error has occurred, error is the error object. The promise object returned by the new Promise constructor has these internal properties: state â€” initially "pending", then changes to either "fulfilled" when resolve is called or "rejected" when reject is called. result â€” initially undefined, then changes to value when resolve(value) called or error when reject(error) is called. ğŸ’¡ There can be only a single result or an error The properties state and result of the Promise object are internal. We canâ€™t directly access them. We can use the methods .then/.catch/.finally for that. await will wait for a Promise value to resolve, otherwise itâ€™ll just wrap the value it is given in a promise and resolve the promise right away. å‚è€ƒï¼š How to get xml2js results out of the parser in ES6? posts.title: 20210916 - Manually set environment variables to Heroku

posts.text: Option 1:We defined the environment variables for development in file .env, but the environment variable that defines the database URL in production should be set to Heroku with the *heroku config:set* command. 1$ heroku config:set MONGODB_URI=mongodb+srv://fullstack:secretpasswordhere@cluster0-ostce.mongodb.net/note-app?retryWrites=true NB: if the command causes an error, give the value of MONGODB_URI in apostrophes: 1$ heroku config:set MONGODB_URI='mongodb+srv://fullstack:secretpasswordhere@cluster0-ostce.mongodb.net/note-app?retryWrites=true' Option 2: (recommended!)Heroku App â†’ Setting â†’ Config Vars Iâ€™ve set MONGODB_URI via git bash but it didnâ€™t work, so I tried one more time by manually setting it on Heroku. It worked!

posts.title: 20210914 - `node xxx.js MY_PASSWORD` caused errors
posts.text: A review of connecting to mongodb â€¦ step 1: Create a new cluster step 2: Select service + region I tried to save data to mongodb. After double checking the password, the IP whitelist and that the connection string was correct, I still got these errors even if I succeeded in creating collections but unfortunately no data was saved to it. save section: 1234note.save().then(result => { console.log('note saved!') mongoose.connection.close()}) mongodb dashboard: Then I followed the steps on Telegram and add catch() to catch errors save section: 1234note.save().then(result => { console.log('note saved!') mongoose.connection.close()}).catch(err => console.log(err)) But still one error left and no data in mongodb dashboard: Eventually I found the solution that successfully saved the data to collection: Anyone else who get this warning when connecting to mongoDB cluster just change the driver version from 3.* to 2.* From connect > connect your application > version select 2.2.* or later So the url section turned to this: 1const url = `mongodb://fullstack:${password}@cluster0-shard-00-00.xfjup.mongodb.net:27017,cluster0-shard-00-01.xfjup.mongodb.net:27017,cluster0-shard-00-02.xfjup.mongodb.net:27017/myFirstDatabase?ssl=true&replicaSet=atlas-rob6kd-shard-0&authSource=admin&retryWrites=true&w=majority` It worked! catch() is not a must for this case And I noticed the INDEXES TOTAL SIZE decreased to 4KB after I tried one more time. Iâ€™m not sure if itâ€™s a bug because the collection still said the Index Size was 20KB. Alright, it turned out to be a bugâ€¦

posts.title: 20210908 - Node (v14 above) isn't supported on win7
posts.slug: 20210908 - Node (v14 above) isn't supported on win7
posts.path: 2021/09/08/20210908 - Node (v14 above) isn't supported on win7/
posts.text:
Possible solution: Node.js 14.x supported on windows 8.1 and above? Â· Issue #33000 Â· nodejs/node NodeJS for windows 7 How to set the NODE_SKIP_PLATFORM_CHECK environment variable to 1 which skips the version check How to set the NODE_SKIP_PLATFORM_CHECK environment variable to 1 which skips the version check How to uninstall node.js completely Windowsä¸‹å®Œå…¨å¸è½½node.jså¹¶å®‰è£…node.jsçš„å¤šç‰ˆæœ¬ç®¡ç†å·¥å…·nvm-windows_ä¸ç§¯è·¬æ­¥ï¼Œæ— ä»¥è‡³åƒé‡Œ-CSDNåšå®¢_windowså¸è½½node Just a short conclusion:First letâ€™s review how to upgrade node.jsstep 1: uninstall existing node.js and delete relevant files (such as C:\Users{User}\AppData\Roaming
pm & C:\Users{User}\AppData\Roaming
pm-cache), then restart the machine step 2: download nvm-setup.zip from github step 3: extract the zip and follow the commands below 1nvm install SPECIFIC_VERSIOIN_YOU_WANT_TO_INSTALL 1nvm use THE_VERSION_YOU_JUST_INSTALLED You can also check the versions youâ€™ve installed with the command nvm list and enter nvm list available to see the versions available to download. Technically done. However, here comes up a problem that unfortunately v14+ of node.js isnâ€™t supported by windows 7. And youâ€™ll get these words when use it: With the help of stackoverflow, I found the solution, hereâ€™s the original answer I pasted: Had same problem and ended solving it, I just installed node 14.15.0 Go here Download the Windows Binary (.zip) either 32/64 bit Extract it in the directory where your node itâ€™s installed and say yes to replace all files (remember that the zip comes with npm that is in node_modules/npm directory I didnâ€™t copy from the zip because I already updated npm before replacing the files) Create an Environment variable called: [NODE_SKIP_PLATFORM_CHECK](https://nodejs.org/api/cli.html#cli_node_skip_platform_check_value) and set it to 1 Ready to use node in Windows 7 for now Hereâ€™s another answer on how to set NODE_SKIP_PLATFORM_CHECK to 1, I had to paste it here too: This work for me Go to System-Properties (run: systempropertiesadvanced.exe), in Advanced tab, click Environment Variables. Still on the System variables, click â€˜Newâ€™, add â€œNODE_PATHâ€ with value â€œC:
odejs64
ode_modulesâ€, and click OK. click â€˜Newâ€™ again, add â€œNODE_SKIP_PLATFORM_CHECKâ€ with value â€œ1â€, and click OK. Click OK of all dialogs close. Restart your machine, so explore and cmd will get the fresh set of variables. SO THANKS TO STACKOVERFLOW, FINALLY I INSTALLED THE LATEST VERSION OF NODE AND SUCCESSFULLY GET IT UP AND RUNNING ON WINDOWS 7! :-)

posts.title: 20210903 - Set Environment Variables & Deal with missing dependencies
posts.slug: 20210903 - Set Environment Variables & Deal with missing dependencies
posts.path: 2021/09/03/20210903 - Set Environment Variables & Deal with missing dependencies/
posts.text: Well, Iâ€™ve just known how to set environment variables. Create a .env (just the name â€˜.envâ€™ is fine) file in the root of your project In the file, add this line: # env REACT_APP_API_KEY=[your_app_api_key] Add const api_key = process.env.REACT_APP_API_KEY to where you need the key Hide your key by adding â€˜.envâ€™ file into gitignore, so that file wont be pushed to github, once you do commit When every step was done, I did set the key and run the application successfully. But hereâ€™s another error I got. I canâ€™t figure out what it means: react_devtools_backend.js:2850 src\components\Weather.js Line 22:6: React Hook useEffect has missing dependencies: â€˜api_keyâ€™ and â€˜profile.capitalâ€™. Either include them or remove the dependency array react-hooks/exhaustive-deps Actually I remember I got this error last time and solved it finally. But this time itâ€™s weird, like, why it had to mention api_key here? And whatâ€™s this dependency array exactly??? Solutions from stackoverflow, but I havenâ€™t tested yet. How to fix missing dependency warning when using useEffect React Hook

posts.title: 20210902 - React Hook useEffect has a missing dependency 'countries'.
posts.slug: 20210902 - React Hook useEffect has a missing dependency 'countries'
posts.path: 2021/09/02/20210902 - React Hook useEffect has a missing dependency 'countries'/
posts.text: webpackHotDevClient.js:138 src\App.jsLine 18:6: React Hook useEffect has a missing dependency: â€˜countriesâ€™. Either include it or remove the dependency array react-hooks/exhaustive-deps App.js 123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839404142434445import axios from "axios";import React, { useState, useEffect} from "react";const App = ({countries}) => { const [countries, setCountries] = useState([]) const [search, setSearch] = useState('') useEffect(() => { console.log('effect') axios .get('https://restcountries.eu/rest/v2/all') .then(response => { console.log('promise fulfilled') console.log(response) setCountries(response.data) // countries.push(response.data) // wrong! you should use setCountries }) }, []) // If the second parameter is an empty array [], then the effect is only run along with the first render of the component. (It just renders the component only once like componentDidMount.) console.log('render', countries.length, 'countries') const handleSearchChange = (event) => { setSearch(event.target.value) // console.log(search) } const searchCountry = search ? countries.filter(country => country.name.toLowerCase().includes (search.toLowerCase()) ) : [] return ( <div> find countries: <input value={search} onChange={handleSearchChange} /> {searchCountry.map(country => <div key={country.name}>{country.name}</div> )} </div> )}export default App; index.js 12345678910import React from 'react';import ReactDOM from 'react-dom';import App from './App';const countries = []ReactDOM.render( <App countries={countries} />, document.getElementById('root')); Note:Donâ€™t directly mutate a state in ReactI attempted to replace useState() with Array.push(). But it didnâ€™t work and instead threw these two errors: For more details: Why canâ€™t I directly modify a componentâ€™s state, really? useEffect()Because useEffect is run after the render of the component, where you can find this rule by the prints below: However, with useState(), it will re-render the component and its state countries will be updated to 250 elements and maintain what it have (re-renders caused by other states wonâ€™t affect its value due to the state is somewhat independent?), and because we add the second parameter [] of useEffect, now it is just run after the first render of the component. And hereâ€™s a good article introducing how useEffect and its parameters work. React.js - How to execute useEffect hook only once?

posts.text: ReferenceIndex as a key is an anti-pattern Index as a key is an anti-pattern ExamplesExample 1WRONG: 1234567891011121314151617181920212223import React from "react";const Note = ({note}) => { return ( <li key={note.id}>{note.content}</li> )}const App = ({ notes }) => { return ( <div> <h1>Notes</h1> <ul> {notes.map(note => <Note note={note}/> )} </ul> </div> )}export default App; Error I got: index.js:1 Warning: Each child in a list should have a unique â€œkeyâ€ prop.Check the render method of App. See https://reactjs.org/link/warning-keys for more information.at Note (http://localhost:3000/static/js/main.chunk.js:24:3)at App (http://localhost:3000/static/js/main.chunk.js:38:3) CORRECT: 1234567891011121314151617181920212223import React from "react";const Note = ({note}) => { return ( <li>{note.content}</li> )}const App = ({ notes }) => { return ( <div> <h1>Notes</h1> <ul> {notes.map(note => <Note key={note.id} note={note}/> )} </ul> </div> )}export default App; ğŸ’¡ Note that the key attribute must now be defined for the Note components, and not for the li tags like before. Example 2ä¸€ä¸ªæ­£ç¡®çš„ä¾‹å­ï¼š 123456789101112131415161718192021222324import React from 'react'const Header = ({name}) => ( <h1>{name}</h1>)const Content = ({parts}) => { return <Part parts={parts}/>}const Part = ({parts}) => { return parts.map(part => <p key={part.id}>{part.name} {part.exercises}</p>)}const Course = ({course}) => { return ( <div> <Header name={course.name}/> <Content parts={course.parts}/> </div> )}export default Course ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥è¿™æ ·å†™ 123456789101112131415161718192021222324import React from 'react'const Header = ({name}) => ( <h1>{name}</h1>)const Content = ({parts}) => { return parts.map(part => <Part key={part.id} part={part}/>)}const Part = ({part}) => { return <p>{part.name} {part.exercises}</p>}const Course = ({course}) => { return ( <div> <Header name={course.name}/> <Content parts={course.parts}/> </div> )}export default Course è¿™ä¸¤ç§å½¢å¼éƒ½å¯ä»¥ï¼Œä¸è¿‡æ¨èç¬¬äºŒç§ï¼Œå„ä¸ªComponentçš„åŠŸèƒ½æ¯”è¾ƒæ¸…æ™°æ˜ç¡®ã€‚ Example 312345678910111213141516const Course = ({courses}) => { return ( <div> {courses.map(course => { return ( <div> <Header key={course.id} name={course.name}/> <Content key={course.id} parts={course.parts}/> </div> ) })} </div> )}export default Course The errors I got: Pass the key attribute to <div>, it works well and no errors pop up 1234567891011121314const Course = ({courses}) => { return ( <div> {courses.map(course => { return ( <div key={course.id}> <Header name={course.name}/> <Content parts={course.parts}/> </div> ) })} </div> )} Some notes keyå±æ€§è¦æ”¾ç½®åˆ°æœ€å¤–å±‚çš„å…ƒç´ æˆ–ç»„ä»¶ä¸­ keyçš„å€¼æœ€å¥½ä¸è¦ä¸ºindex æœ€å¤–å±‚æ˜¯<React.Fragment>æ—¶ä¹Ÿä¸€æ ·è¦æ”¾keyå±æ€§ã€‚
